title: South African mayor incorrect about Covid-19 ‘vaccine’
subtitle: To help fight the coronavirus, Ekurhuleni wants to buy “the vaccine” interferon alpha-2b from Cuba, the city’s mayor Mzwandile Masina said recently. The drug has been used to treat other coronavirus diseases, but it’s no vaccine.
author: africacheck.org
vclaim:
• None Mzwandile Masina, mayor of the City of Ekurhuleni, said he would use emergency funds “to procure the vaccine Inferon B from Cuba” to help fight the coronavirus outbreak.
• None He appears to have been referring to interferon alpha-2b, a drug used to treat the symptoms of diseases caused by some earlier strains of coronavirus. But it’s not a vaccine that would prevent Covid-19.
• None Experts stressed that misinformation during the coronavirus crisis would only work against efforts to slow the spread of the pandemic.

Masina referred to “Inferon B” as a vaccine in his speech but an

a photo a few hours before delivering the speech, captioned “Interferon B”, of boxes of interferon alpha-2b. This is a man made form of an interferon, a substance produced in various forms by the human immune system. Interferon alpha-2b is a cytokine.

“That’s a chemical produced by the white blood cells, your immune cells, that helps to protect you against infection including viruses,” said immunologist Dr Elizabeth Mayne, who works at South Africa’s

But interferon alpha-2b, according to Mayne, is “definitively not a vaccine”. “There is no good scientific data to show that it will protect you from getting the infection."

The day before Masina made his claim, Cuba’s foreign affairs ministry released a statement that “there is no preventive vaccine or specific treatment, at this time, for the new coronavirus”.

It said, however, that it was producing interferon alpha-2b “in addition to another group of drugs that are included in protocols for treating patients with this disease and the complications that may arise”.

Interferon alpha-2b and other interferons have been used to treat previous strains of coronavirus because of their ability to boost cells’ natural defence mechanisms. They

to share similarities with the 2019 coronavirus.

But the treatment can have serious side effects. The American Society of Health-System Pharmacists

Mayne described the common side effects as: “All of the things that make you feel pretty miserable when you have the flu: the tiredness, the fatigue, not wanting to eat, things like that”. The side effects of interferon therapy mean that “a lot of people actually can’t take it”.
